org.stekikun.dolmen.codegen

Class LexBuffer

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.stekikun.dolmen.codegen.LexBuffer

  • public class LexBuffer
extends Object
    Instances of buffers used by generated lexers.

    Lexical analysers actually extend this class to inherit a buffer with markers for token positions, final states, and methods which are used by the generated automata, as well as methods that can be used in semantic actions.

    Author:
    St√©phane Lescuyer

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  LexBuffer.LexicalError
      Exception which can be raised by generated lexers which extend LexBuffer, and which is raised also by getNextChar() in place of potential IOExceptions.
      static class  LexBuffer.Position
      Instances of this class describe a position in some input (most frequently a file, but could be a string or any char sequence).

    • Method Detail

      • getNextChar

        protected final char getNextChar()
        Returns:
        the next character in buffer, with the special value 0xFFFF used to denote end-of-input

      • startToken

        protected final void startToken()
        Starts the matching of a new token

      • mark

        protected final void mark(int action)
        Marks the current position as the last terminal state encountered
        Parameters:
        action - associated semantic action index

      • rewind

        protected final int rewind()
        Resets the current position to the last terminal state encountered
        Returns:
        the recorded semantic action

      • endToken

        protected final void endToken()
        Ends the matching of the current token

      • peekNextChar

        protected final char peekNextChar()
        This function is useful in cases when a lexer's semantic action must act depending on what kind of input follows the current token in the stream (although arguably at that point it's not lexing anymore but parsing!).
        Returns:
        the next character in the stream (-1 for end-of-input) but does not advance the lexer engine

      • peekNextChars

        protected final int peekNextChars(char[] chars)
        This function fetches the next characters in the stream and returns them into the given character buffer chars. It does so without advancing the state of the lexing engine so that on return the lexer can resume from the original position.

        This function is useful in cases when a lexer's semantic action must act depending on what kind of input follows the current token in the stream (although arguably at that point it's not lexing anymore but parsing!).

        Returns:
        the number of look-ahead characters from the stream actually inserted into chars
        See Also:
        peekNextChar()

      • changeInput

        protected final void changeInput(String filename,
                                 Reader reader)
        This changes the input stream used by this lexer buffer to the new source described by filename and reader.

        In contrast to pushInput(String, java.io.Reader), this does not allow resuming the analysis of the former stream once the new one is complete. This takes care of closing the input stream which was in use until that point.

        Parameters:
        filename -
        reader -

      • pushInput

        protected final void pushInput(String filename,
                               Reader reader)
        This pushes the current input stream to the internal input stack and resets the lexer to read from the given reader. Subsequent tokens will consume characters from the new stream.

        The syntactic analysis of the former input stream can be resumed in the exact same position by a subsequent call to popInput().

        Parameters:
        filename - name of the new input source
        reader - new input character stream

      • hasMoreInput

        protected final boolean hasMoreInput()
        Returns:
        true if and only if there is more input to fall back to once the current input stream is over, i.e. if popInput() will succeed

      • popInput

        protected final void popInput()
        This fetches the input stream which is at the stop of the input stack. After this call, the lexer will continue reading from that input in the exact spot where it was interrupted by a call to pushInput(String, java.io.Reader).

        This takes care of closing the input stream which was in use until that point.

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - when the input stack is empty
        See Also:
        hasMoreInput()

      • getLexeme

        protected final String getLexeme()
        Returns:
        the substring between the last started token and the current position (exclusive)

      • getLexemeStart

        public final LexBuffer.Position getLexemeStart()
        Returns:
        the position of the last lexeme start

      • getLexemeEnd

        public final LexBuffer.Position getLexemeEnd()
        Returns:
        the position of the last lexeme end

      • getLexemeLength

        public final int getLexemeLength()
        Returns:
        the length of the last matched lexeme

      • getLexemeChar

        public final char getLexemeChar(int idx)
        When successful, this is equivalent to getLexeme().charAt(idx), but will be more efficient in general.
        Parameters:
        idx -
        Returns:
        the character at index idx in the last matched lexeme
        Throws:
        LexBuffer.LexicalError - when idx is negative or not less than the length of the lexeme

                                    int end)
        Parameters:

        end -
        Returns:
        the substring between positions pos and end (exclusive) in the token buffer

                                                 int end)
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the (optional) substring between positions pos and end (exclusive) in the token buffer

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the character at position pos in the token buffer

        protected final Optional<Character> getSubLexemeOptChar(int pos)
        Parameters:
        pos -
        Returns:
        the (optional) character at position pos in the token buffer

      • error

        protected LexBuffer.LexicalError error(String msg)
        Convenience helper which returns a LexBuffer.LexicalError located at the current lexeme start.

        It is also used by the lexer generator to report empty tokens, i.e. input which does not match any of the lexer rules. It can be overriden in generated lexers to allow for customized message and position reports.

        Parameters:
        msg -
        Returns:
        the exception with the given message and the current token start position

      • newline

        protected final void newline()
        Updates the current position to account for a line change. Is not called automatically by the lexer, but can be used in semantic actions when matching a newline character.

      • saveStart

        protected final <T> T saveStart(Supplier<T> supplier)
        Same as savePosition(java.util.function.Supplier<T>, org.stekikun.dolmen.codegen.LexBuffer.Position)(supplier, getLexemeStart()).

        This is exactly equivalent to the following code: 

           Position saved = getLexemeStart();
   T res = supplier.get();      // Calling the routine
   startLoc = saved;            // Restoring the start position

        Parameters:
        supplier - a routine to run
        Returns:
        the value returned by running the given supplier
        See Also:
        savePosition(Supplier, Position), getLexemeStart()

      • savePosition

        protected final <T> T savePosition(Supplier<T> supplier,
                                   LexBuffer.Position saved)
        This method runs the given supplier routine but takes care to restore the current token start position to the position given as the saved parameter.

        This is exactly equivalent to the following code: 

           T res = supplier.get();      // Calling the routine
   startLoc = saved;            // Restoring the start position
        This is useful in semantic actions which have only recognized part of a syntactic construct (typically a complex literal opening delimiter, such as the opening double-quote of a literal string) and which call other rules of the lexer recursively in order to finish analyzing the current construct. In such cases, one may want to return the final resulting token as if its span covered the whole range from the opening construct. Calling nested rules inside a lambda passed to this method is a way to achieve this.
        Parameters:
        supplier - a routine to run
        saved - the starting position to save
        Returns:
        the value returned by running the given supplier
        See Also:
        saveStart(Supplier)

      • saveStart

        protected final void saveStart(Runnable runnable)
        Same as savePosition(java.util.function.Supplier<T>, org.stekikun.dolmen.codegen.LexBuffer.Position)(runnable, getLexemeStart()).

        This is exactly equivalent to the following code: 

           Position saved = getLexemeStart();
   supplier.run();      // Calling the routine
   startLoc = saved;            // Restoring the start position

        Parameters:
        runnable - a routine to run
        See Also:
        savePosition(Runnable, Position), getLexemeStart()

      • savePosition

        protected final void savePosition(Runnable runnable,
                                  LexBuffer.Position saved)
        This method runs the given runnable but takes care to restore the current token start position to the position given as the saved parameter.

        This is exactly equivalent to the following code: 

           supplier.run();      // Calling the routine
   startLoc = saved;            // Restoring the start position
        This is useful in semantic actions which have only recognized part of a syntactic construct (typically a complex literal opening delimiter, such as the opening double-quote of a literal string) and which call other rules of the lexer recursively in order to finish analyzing the current construct. In such cases, one may want to return the final resulting token as if its span covered the whole range from the opening construct. Calling nested rules inside a lambda passed to this method is a way to achieve this.
        Parameters:
        runnable - a routine to run
        saved - the starting position to save
        See Also:
        saveStart(Runnable)
